title: 113_s1252
content: The Act is titled the "Upper Missisquoi and Trout Wild and Scenic Rivers Act" and designates specific river segments as wild and scenic. The Wild and Scenic Rivers Act is amended to include the Missisquoi River and Trout River segments in Vermont, designated as recreational rivers. The Trout River segment in Vermont, from Montgomery to East Berkshire, is designated as a recreational river under the Wild and Scenic Rivers Act. SEC. 3. MANAGEMENT. The river segments designated by paragraph (208) of section 3(a) of the Wild and Scenic Rivers Act shall be managed in accordance with the Upper Missisquoi and Trout Rivers Management Plan and any approved amendments by the Secretary and the Committee. The management plan finalized in March 2013, and any subsequent amendments, satisfy the requirements for a comprehensive management plan under the Wild and Scenic Rivers Act. The Secretary of the Interior will coordinate management responsibilities with the Committee as outlined in the plan. The Secretary may enter into cooperative agreements for the protection and enhancement of designated river segments. The Wild and Scenic Rivers Act allows for cooperative agreements with Vermont, specific municipalities, and organizations for river management. Agreements must align with the management plan and may involve US assistance. Designation of river segments does not impact existing hydroelectric facilities. The Wild and Scenic Rivers Act allows for cooperative agreements with Vermont for river management, aligning with the management plan and involving US assistance. It does not impact existing hydroelectric facilities. The Act precludes the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission from authorizing the operation of certain hydroelectric projects, unless changes are deemed consistent with the designation by the Secretary of the Interior. Regulatory Commission hydropower proceedings may be located within designated river segments under the Wild and Scenic Rivers Act, subject to Secretary's approval. Zoning ordinances in Vermont towns align with conservation provisions for designated river segments. The State of Vermont's conservation provisions for designated river segments satisfy the standards of the Wild and Scenic Rivers Act. Land acquisitions for these segments are limited to donation or with owner consent, subject to management plan criteria. The relation to the National Park System is specified despite certain Act provisions. The Missisquoi and Trout Rivers are exempt from National Park System regulations under the Wild and Scenic Rivers Act. A 3.8-mile segment of the Missisquoi River may be designated as a recreational river with local support. Land acquisitions for designated river segments in Vermont are limited to donation or with owner consent. The Secretary of the Interior will designate an additional segment of the Missisquoi River as a recreational river if there is adequate local support. The segment will be administered as a recreational river under the Wild and Scenic Rivers Act. The Missisquoi River segment in Lowell, Vermont can be designated as a recreational river with majority voter support.
